title: This Boston restaurant is one of the top-grossing independent eateries in the country - Restaurants
text:
Abe & Louie’s, one of Back Bay’s swanky steakhouses, was one the highest-grossing independent restaurants in the country in 2014, Restaurant Business reported.
The Boylston Street spot raked in $16.2 million last year, with the average bill per table coming in at $78, according to Restaurant Business. That made Abe & Louie’s the 40th highest grossing independent eatery in the nation, and the only New England-based restaurant to break the top 100.
See the full list from Restaurant Business here .

The restaurant has a classy upstairs, along with more casual seating downstairs at the bar or patio. Address: 30 Gloucester St. Casa Romero Previous -- of -- Next At Liquid Art House, a spacious restaurant/gallery hybrid, plates are as artistic as the rotating art exhibitions. It’s a kill-many-birds-with-one-stone kind of place, with art as decor and for sale, an ecclectic scene, and eye-popping food. Address: 100 Arlington St. The Boston Globe/Essdras M Suarez Previous -- of -- Next Sonsie is one of the city’s best spots for people-watching. Many of the tables face Newbury Street, and their floor-to-ceiling windows stay open during the warm months. Add that to a bottle of wine, and you have one entertaining afternoon. Address: 327 Newbury St. The Boston Globe/Wendy Maeda Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Mistral’s elegant decor is reminiscent of southern France while accenting classic French cuisine with seasonal ingredients and spices. Spend an evening here if you’re looking to enjoy duck confit, prime sirloin carpaccio, or roasted hen. Address: 223 Columbus Ave. The Boston Globe/Josh Reynolds Previous -- of -- Next Piattini Wine Cafe is dedicated to serving small dishes of pasta, antipasti, bruschetta, and more. Address: 226 Newbury St. Piattini Wine Cafe/Josephine Megwa Previous -- of -- Next Unlike traditional oyster shacks, Select Oyster Bar explores coastal cuisines from locales like Cuba, Portugal, and Greece. The restaurant complements its dishes with a laid-back atmosphere, seating customers at a communal table, the bar, or private patio. Address: 50 Gloucester St. The Boston Globe/John Tlumacki Previous -- of -- Next Technically in Bay Village, this spot is so good we’ll let it slide. Mike & Patty’s is a hole-in-the-wall that attracts customers with its array of breakfast sandwiches. While a typical egg-and-cheese is available, go with the “Fancy”: two fried eggs, cheddar cheese, bacon, avocado, red onions, and mayo on toasted bread. Address: 12 Church St. Mike & Patty’s/Dan Watkins
